content: In the following problems, you will be given a series of propositions as premises and a proof obligation. The premises are in the form '(1) xxx. (2) xxx. (3) xxx. ...', and the proof obligation is in the form 'Prove: (n) xxx.' You need to provide the minimal set of premise propositions such that the proof obligation can be derived from the given premises. You should present the result in the form '(1),(2),(3),...->(n)', where the propositions on the left side of the arrow are separated by commas and represent the premise numbers, and the right side of the arrow represents the proof obligation number. Please ensure that the propositions on the left side of the arrow are presented in the order of their introduction in the proof process, meaning each proposition's introduction must be consistent with the derivation process (for example, the first two propositions might derive an intermediate conclusion, which then can be combined with a third proposition for further derivation). The answer should only be in the form '(1),(2),(3),...->(n)' without any additional text.(Notice that If the same reasoning premises have their labels and content reassigned, the two reasoning processes should remain consistent in content, with only the labels changed.)

Premises: [(1) Everything that is liquid, wooden, metallic, luminous, and a gorpus is a sterpus. (2) Everything that is kind and angry and aggressive and amenable and a lempus is a vumpus. (3) Everything that is bitter and sweet and spicy and sour and a gorpus is a lempus. (4) Everything that is bright and dull and a lempus is a tumpus. (5) Everything that is shy and nervous and happy and feisty and an impus is a yumpus. (6) Alex is wooden. (7) Alex is liquid. (8) Alex is metallic. (9) Alex is a gorpus. (10) Alex is bitter. (11) Alex is angry. (12) Alex is an impus. (13) Alex is spicy. (14) Alex is luminous. (15) Alex is sweet. (16) Alex is aggressive. (17) Alex is amenable. (18) Alex is kind. (19) Alex is sour.] Prove: (20) Alex is kind, angry, aggressive, amenable, and a lempus.

The minimal set of premise propositions to derive (20) Alex is kind, angry, aggressive, amenable, and a lempus from the given premises is: [(1) Everything that is liquid, wooden, metallic, luminous, and a gorpus is a sterpus. (6) Alex is wooden. (18) Alex is kind.]

The reasoning process is as follows:

(1) Everything that is liquid, wooden, metallic, luminous, and a gorpus is a sterpus. - Given
(6) Alex is wooden. - Given
(18) Alex is kind. - Given
(1) and (6) combined infer that Alex is liquid, metallic, and luminous.
(1) and (18) infer that Alex is a sterpus.
(2) Everything that is kind and angry and aggressive and amenable and a lempus is a vumpus. - To prove
(18) combined with the definition of vumpus infer that Alex is also aggressive and amenable.
(1), (6), and (18) combined with the definition of lempus infer that Alex is also liquid, wooden, and metallic.
(1), (6), (18), and (20) infer that Alex is kind, angry, aggressive, amenable, and a lempus.

Therefore, the minimal set of premise propositions to prove (20) Alex is kind, angry, aggressive, amenable, and a lempus is [(1), (6), (18)].

Premises: [(1) Alex is sour. (2) Alex is kind. (3) Alex is amenable. (4) Alex is aggressive. (5) Alex is sweet. (6) Alex is luminous. (7) Alex is spicy. (8) Alex is an impus. (9) Alex is angry. (10) Alex is bitter. (11) Alex is a gorpus. (12) Alex is metallic. (13) Alex is liquid. (14) Alex is wooden. (15) Everything that is shy and nervous and happy and feisty and an impus is a yumpus. (16) Everything that is bright and dull and a lempus is a tumpus. (17) Everything that is bitter and sweet and spicy and sour and a gorpus is a lempus. (18) Everything that is kind and angry and aggressive and amenable and a lempus is a vumpus. (19) Everything that is liquid, wooden, metallic, luminous, and a gorpus is a sterpus.] Prove: (20) Alex is kind, angry, aggressive, amenable, and a lempus.

The minimal set of premise propositions to prove (20) Alex is kind, angry, aggressive, amenable, and a lempus from the given premises is: [(1) Alex is sour. (2) Alex is kind. (5) Alex is sweet. (7) Alex is spicy. (9) Alex is angry. (13) Alex is liquid.]

The reasoning process is as follows:

(1) Alex is sour - Given
(2) Alex is kind - Given
(5) Alex is sweet - Given
(7) Alex is spicy - Given
(9) Alex is angry - Given
(13) Alex is liquid - Given
(1), (2), and (5) infer that Alex is also sweet and spicy.
(1), (7), and (9) infer that Alex is also sour and angry.
(1), (9), and (17) infer that Alex is also a gorpus.
(1), (13), and (18) infer that Alex is also amenable and aggressive.
(1), (19), and (20) infer that Alex is also a lempus.

Therefore, the minimal set of premise propositions to prove (20) Alex is kind, angry, aggressive, amenable, and a lempus is [(1), (5), (7), (9), (13)].
